name: thedailybeast
text:
Civil unrest that has caused injury to protesters is also impacting healthcare workers fighting the COVID-19 crisis. 

Rayne Valentine, 32, described his horrifying interaction with law enforcement to The Daily Beast. https://t.co/b4TriGrDFu

name: thedailybeast
text:
After leaving his shift at Kings County Hospital Center, Valentine encountered NYPD officers chasing a protester from a nearby rally. He began recording with his phone.

“I stayed out of the way,” he said. “I didn’t say anything to antagonize them.” https://t.co/b4TriGrDFu

name: thedailybeast
text:
Next thing, he was lying in the fetal position on a sidewalk after being kicked and beaten by the police.
 
Valentine said he told the officers, “I’m just trying to go home,” but they responded: “Well, you picked the wrong time to do that.”  https://t.co/b4TriGrDFu

name: thedailybeast
text:
“I don’t know if it’s because they noticed my hospital ID or if it’s because they saw the blood, but they stopped, threw my phone at me, and I walked back to the hospital,” said Valentine.

He got seven staples in his head and two CT scans. https://t.co/0sEOXP0Aet

name: thedailybeast
text:
Other medical workers, EMTs, and firefighters have become victims of police violence as members of street medic teams. 

Some, such as in Denver, were reportedly tear-gassed while treating protesters at makeshift clinics. https://t.co/0sEOXP0Aet

name: thedailybeast
text: “They weren’t just indiscriminately arresting people, but they were targeting people doing first aid,” another street medic in New York told The Daily Beast. “It’s very distressing. It feels similar to seeing them targeting journalists.”  https://t.co/0sEOXP0Aet

name: thedailybeast
text: Read the full story by @OliviaMesser here: https://t.co/0sEOXP0Aet
